Hot new bombshells enter the villa.

Otherwise invisible to the unaided eye, infrared data from 
@NASAWebb
 and x-ray data from 
@ChandraXray
 make details in these proper fit cosmic wonders available by mapping the data to colors that humans can perceive:
https://go.nasa.gov/43wTsx9

We completed a joint checkpoint review with @BoeingSpace ahead of the first #Starliner flight to carry astronauts, set for no earlier than July 21. Teams will provide updates leading up to the inaugural Crew Flight Test to and from the @Space_Station: https://go.nasa.gov/3MZR1xG

Hot new bombshells enter the villa.

Otherwise invisible to the unaided eye, infrared data from @NASAWebb and x-ray data from @ChandraXray make details in these proper fit cosmic wonders available by mapping the data to colors that humans can perceive:
https://go.nasa.gov/43wTsx9

Completing a squad of severe weather satellites, testing out a ssssnake-like robot, and sending the second all-private astronaut mission to the @Space_Station—all in a week’s work at NASA. See what we’ve been up to.

We’re launching solar arrays, small satellites, and a plant experiment to the @Space_Station on the next @SpaceX cargo mission, set for June 3.

Tune in on May 30 at 2pm ET (1800 UTC) for details. #AskNASA your questions and we may answer them on-air. https://go.nasa.gov/430oldn

We can’t imagine a more beautiful thing than May’s full moon – the Corn Moon. 

Set to peak on May 5 at 1:34pm ET (1634 UTC ), this full moon, also known as the Flower Moon, will appear full till Sunday. Discover how it got its names: http://go.nasa.gov/3piIAUs
Four of Uranus’ largest moons—Ariel, Umbriel, Titania, and Oberon—may have oceans beneath their icy crusts, according to a re-analysis of Voyager 2 data. https://go.nasa.gov/3VQtF0l

It’s a TRAP(PIST)-1! 

About 40 light-years away lies a planetary system with the most Earth-sized exoplanets found in a star's habitable zone. Learn more about the TRAPPIST-1 system that was recently studied by 
@NASAWebb
: http://go.nasa.gov/415DmsC

#MayTheFourth

When we say “supermassive black holes,” just how do they measure up? 

Using their shadows for size, we’ve rounded up 10 black holes and compared them to objects in our solar system. Don’t worry – these black holes are many light-years away: https://go.nasa.gov/3HIcDeW #BlackHoleWeek

The eta Aquariid meteor shower is expected to reach its peak tonight (May 4-5)—and even with the full Moon, it could still be a great night for skywatching!

Here's how, where and when to track the eta Aquariids: https://go.nasa.gov/42iqGQk

Bring balance to the force, not leave it in darkness.

Happy #StarWarsDay. And #MayThe4thBeWithYou.

This week at NASA, we marked the Ingenuity #MarsHelicopter's 50th flight on the Red Planet, the planet-hunting satellite TESS entered its fifth year, and we celebrated our favorite planet—Earth!

Celebrate #EarthDay with us: https://go.nasa.gov/40AeM2G
Share if you love Earth.  #EarthDay

Happy #EarthDay 

From the tallest peaks to ocean depths, from arid deserts to lush forests, we observe our home from a unique perspective. Learn about the activities all around NASA, and about the picture that kicked off this celebration of our planet: https://go.nasa.gov/41yzVvI

Happy Earth Day from me and our good friends over at NASA.
 
For our children and grandchildren, we must stand united in our effort to save our only home.

What was it like when Apollo 8 astronaut Bill Anders saw Earth rise over the Moon’s horizon in 1968?

He reflects with Dr. Kate Calvin, NASA senior climate advisor and chief scientist, on taking the famous photo helped humanity "discover" Earth. https://go.nasa.gov/43QKQCr

#EarthDay

Live Now: Watch as the uncrewed 
@NorthropGrumman
 S.S. Sally Ride Cygnus cargo spacecraft departs from the 
@Space_Station
.

The spacecraft delivered snacks, science, and supplies to the orbiting laboratory in November 2022:
http://go.nasa.gov/3MWtqhI

We celebrate International #HumanSpaceFlight Day honoring the accomplishments of the first person in space in 1961, and the first launch of the space shuttle in 1981. 

Next, with 
@NASAArtemis
, we continue humanity’s progress with Moon & Mars exploration!

Tail installed 

Soon, 
@NASAAero
’s X-59 will take to the skies to demonstrate a new quiet form of supersonic flight. This technology could bring a return to supersonic flight over land—cutting flight times in half. More on the Quesst mission: https://nasa.gov/specials/Quesst/…

What's new on the Web(b)?

We always have the latest hi-res images from 
@NASAWebb
 available to view (and download) at http://webbtelescope.org. Stop by and make sure you haven't missed any!

Designed to endure at least 7 passes through Jupiter's intense radiation, the JunoCam instrument has survived 50 so far – and it’s still going strong. In this new @googlearts exhibition, celebrate the otherworldly vistas “the public’s camera” has shown us: https://artsandculture.google.com/story/XwUxhKx1GDOOTA…

The #JunoMission completed its 50th close pass of Jupiter this past weekend. Relive highlights from its journey around the solar system’s largest planet, download high-res images and learn more: https://go.nasa.gov/40ZRrIQ
